reviews.review_text: THIS GAME.  THIS ♥♥♥♥ING GAME.  BUYING THIS GAME WAS ONE OF THE WORST MISTAKES I EVER MADE.   I started this game up expecting to have a good time, as I did with the other Fallout games. I'd played Fallout 1, and I'd heard from almost everyone that Fallout 2 was FAR superior. I throroughly enjoyed Fallout 1, but my main problem with it was that the game was timed, and practically forced you to rush through it. Because of this, I felt as though my experience with the game was cut short. The main thing I was looking for when I started playing Fallout 2 was a lengthier game that would allow me to explore and progress at my own pace.  I got more than I could have ever hoped for.  The game started out slow, much like many other RPGs, and frankly, it was a bit boring for the first few hours. But I knew from my previous experiences that Fallout games only get better as you progress. I made it through the first few areas, and started getting a feel for how things worked, finding plenty of new quests, etc. It was becoming rather enjoyable, then I got the car, which would allow me to carry more things, and explore the wasteland with much more ease. It was very exciting, almost like getting my first car all over again. And at that point I was hooked.  Everything from that point on is a bit of a blur, I remember traveling from city to city, back and forth, looking for every quest I could possibly find. The process of finding better and better gear for my three companions was addicting, the process of ensuring the prosperity of all the settlements was addicting, the atmosphere is addicting, becoming famous for various reasons across the wasteland was addicting, the fact that the game goes into so much detail and lets you influence the way things play out was addicting. EVERYTHING ABOUT THIS GAME IS ADDICTING!  I couldn't help it, hours and hours of my life were being sucked away, and there was nothing I could to about it except keep playing. IT WAS AMAZING.  The final toll was a little over 66 hours for me. And that was all spent on a single playthrough. When I FINALLY beat the game, I felt a feeling of happiness and satisfaction that I haven't felt in YEARS. But most of all, I felt an overwhelming sense of FREEDOM. NO LONGER WAS I SHACKLED BY ITS IMMENSE QUALITY, BY ITS SHEER BEAUTY. I will never play this game for the first time again, that makes me both relieved and depressed. Depressed, because this game is phenomenal, because it is one of the best games I ever played. But relieved, because I will never lose that many hours that quickly ever again.  This game is a true gem. It is an incredible, immersive experience even by today's standards, and in fact, shïts all over most modern RPGs.  That's the problem, though, this game is TOO GOOD. DO NOT PLAY THIS GAME UNLESS YOU HAVE ABSOLUTELY NOTHING TO LOSE.     Now if you'll excuse me, I'm gonna start my evil playthough.

Just over a decade ago, life was simpler and more frivolous, so every fictional discovery was fascinating and entertaining. It was in that simple, mid-teenage life, that I dug Fallout 2 out of a fortunate coincidence. A disc copy of the game, in a modest gaming magazine, to whose cover it was poorly attached. It seemed interesting enough, and with little knowledge of cRPGs or English, I went home and gave it a try. Boy, was I enthralled by this game. A game which would, about ten years later, still be the most cherished piece of gaming I have ever experienced.   Fallout 2 ventures deep into the dark territories of humour and morbidity. Not many have the grit for its atmosphere, inauspicious and heavy as it is, its dense soundtrack that evinces feelings of gloomy solitude and decadence; exactly the vibe you have got to be in when playing any Fallout title, for that matter. Back when I first tried it, I would engage in conflicts between the curiosity to explore its narrative and the uneasiness caused by that very atmosphere, even after having previously and briefly tried Planescape: Torment - an equally dense game. Fortunately for me, I got past that.  Provided that you can also overcome such uneasiness, you've got an unparallelled RPG challenge ahead of you. Fallout 2, very much like its predecessor, is beautifully written, and cleverly designed in a way that connects your actions to the realities and contextual changes of Northern California as you go. The turn-based combat is typical late-90s cRPG gold. The S.P.E.C.I.A.L role-playing system, a jewel derived from Gurps, offers you that edge of character construction and skill management that makes a bonafide RPG pleasurable. The post-apocalyptic setting and aesthetics, built on the famous premise of the Divergence - the historical fragmentation in which the fictional linearity of the game took a different course from that of our world in the heat of the Cold War, leaving the former with that futuristic-50s style -, renders Fallout's identity unique and typically dark humoured. Its characters are deeply unpredictable and credible, especially the companions, much more mature than those of the previous installment (with all due respect to the likes of Ian and Dogmeat). The game leaves that bitter feeling of longing in the player's mouth should they pass away or have to be left behind for some reason. Each companion adds to the player's enterprise, each has their own story, each has their own passions and motivations. And flaws.  Fallout 2 appeals to multiple audiences. Those looking for an RPG; those looking for a post-apocalyptic piece; those looking for a story-driven game; those looking for open-world dynamic narratives; those looking for a demi-horror title; and so forth. While it may not touch some of these categories in depth, it is a game that brings them all to a perfect harmony. Be ready for a challenge, an unforgiving gameplay, but be also ready for enriching rewards that will open your mind to new spheres of role-playing gaming.

Nearly twenty years after the fact, this is still my favorite RPG. With the exception of New Vegas, this was the last official Fallout game in which the skill system was, in fact, meaningful and had a significant effect on gameplay.  Do you want to be something of a pacifist, with high speech, intelligence, and survivalist skills who runs for cover at the first sign of a fight and has his companions do all the heavy lifting for him? Go for it, Skeeter.  How about a post-apocalyptic hard-♥♥♥ who just wants to make a living skinning giant geckos and selling off discarded raider gear? You can do that too. The game does have a story and it is actually pretty good, but you're likely going to spend more time doing just about everything else than you are folliwng the main plot, and that is a very good thing.  The graphics have not aged particularly well, and the game takes some minor adjusting on a modern rig in order to make it work and look properly, but seriously, don't let that stop you. Once you get used to the visual style, the pixel hunt-like searches for items dropped on the floor becomes the least of your concerrns.  You will be far more interested in the cavalcade of goodies that's just fallen to the ground alongside the raider whose chest you've blasted a whole clear through.  Also you can murder children, and acquire a perk which reflects said habit of killing children. Game of the year, all years.

The hype is spot on for this classic, it actually is not blind nostalgia when it is said that this game allows for far more role-playing than every other video game in existence.  Fallout 2 is not bound by modern day game design limitations and rules, it does things modern games are afraid to do. It was designed by the most talented game studio of all time, Black Isle Studios, with much of the excellence being on showcase in Planescape: Torment which was released the following year. Largely a different kind of excellence, but both games are so much more original and limitless than anything today. Everything you do in Fallout 2 leads to some reaction, big or small, but usually somewhat realistic. When playing the game you have to think twice about what you say and how you act.   Keep talking to someone who doesn't want to be bothered, and there may actually be consequences. Sneak around in the open and people will question you. Walk around with a weapon equipped in certain places and you may find yourself being fired upon. Throw away First Citizen Lynette's trust and say goodbye to Vault City forever. Become a boxing champion in New Reno and you will be famous and respected in that area, with the townsfolk calling you 'Champ' most of the time. Play as a cold blooded, ruthless killer and you will be feared and certain quests will open up to you while others will become unavailable. Finish the main quest in a positive way and you will be hailed a hero in most places. Play as a low intelligence character and watch the whole game transform appropriately (look it up on YouTube if you must). The list goes on, these are just some examples of the attention to detail in Fallout 2 that no other game exhibits.  Fallout 2 is also a very good satire, less serious than its modern counterparts. If you've only played Fallout 3 and Fallout 4 then you've barely experienced Fallout. New Vegas is an impressive sequel however, but still more 'gamey' and with less role-playing.

In some ways, this is a direct improvement over the first. There is more stuff to do, more stuff to unlock, bigger map, etc. The character customization is deeper. That's all fine.  However, what I appreciated about the first game were its simple objectives with various free-form solutions. Fallout 2 seems to strip these away in favor of increasingly complex and awkward quests. Often, they will require speaking with specific characters who are almost indistinguishable from other, less important NPCs, and doing so in a specific procedure. The Gecko Power Plant quest is a good example of how this, combined with a lot of tedious running around, results in a tiresome game of 'who's who'. Of course, the player usually has a choice in these sorts of situations to take a moral shortcut for negative karma, but the rewards for pursuing a 'good' outcome pretty much always outweigh the rewards for 'bad' behavior. I prefer to finish quests in as complete a fashion as I can, but their weird, constricted structure here bores and angers me.  Other times, logic is sacrificed for the sake of creating gameplay. I understand that Vault 13, literally a hole in the side of a mountain, could be easily ignored, but if this Pipboy is the same one that belonged to the Vault Dweller, wouldn't it make sense for the locations canonically visited in the previous game to be on it already? At least the military base should be on there, if not the vault, but at least it's not hidden to the point of requiring a quest for exploration; Speaking of bases, what about the Sierra Army Depot? It sounds and looks like it would be big enough to be noticed just by going near it, but nope, it only appears when a certain quest is activated. There's also the Enclave power armor that's good at fooling Enclave soldiers in every situation save for the map's random events, but whatever, I'm sure someone with nothing better to do has come up with an explanation for all this. Bottom line is, the first game did not do this sort of thing. It let the player reap the full benefits of accidental discovery.  A large map is good, but the random events happen WAY too often. I breathe less often than I encounter something on the map screen. Almost every time, the enemies appearing in these events are too hard (instant death), too plentiful (slow, agonizing death), or easily outrun (waste of time). Save scumming becomes a necessity for travelling through particularly brutal areas, such as the region around Navarro, where movement needs to be taken an inch at a time, lest I come across a patrol and get a one-way ticket to the game over screen. Get the car, because that ♥♥♥♥ happens a lot less often, although there is still the occasional stop made involuntary for whatever reason.  Overall, the game is representative of living in modern day California; It's buggy (frame drops, some crashing), very disorganized, and constantly frustrating, but it has its moments, and it gets more fun after the first few hours. Bigger? Yes. Better? Maybe. It's still worth playing.

To this very day Fallout 2 is one of the best games that I've ever laid hands on. I played it back in school for hundreds of hours and now that you can get it on Steam, I just had to buy it once more. Its graphics might seem quite outdated, but if you're not too much of a superficial gamer, you should be able to deal with it.  What makes this game so incredibly beautiful is the developers' love for details and a really convincing atmosphere. You get thrown into a post-apocalyptic world full of glorious black humour, knowing only little about your actual main quest. There is barely any hand-holding, which modern RPGs do all too much. In Fallout 2 there are no quest markers, only hints. To solve your missions, you have to listen to what NPCs tell you, instead of clicking right through dialogues, following a pointer on your minimap and shooting a few bandits in the face. As most things in Fallout 2 can be done in a variety of ways, you can solve problems by talking, violence, in favor of your own interests or to help a certain person or faction. And the outcome will always be entirely different. You decide everything.  On your way through the radioactive desert of the American West Coast you will discover tons of secrets, interesting characters, quests and enthralling side stories. Considering its release date, the game's actually huge. I've played Fallout an infinite number of times, but so far I always managed to discover something new - be it a secret area, a new way to solve a certain quest or just another crazy NPC.  As if this wasn't enough cool things to know about Fallout 2 already, there's even more. For example Fallout's unique character creation system. Your avatar will have a truckload of skills, talents, perks and attributes, which have a direct influence on the gameplay and everything else. You want to conquer the wasteland as a highly intelligent scientist and sweet-talker instead of being a violent brute? Want to be a sniper instead of chopping your enemies with a chainsaw knife? Well, just give it a shot. No two playthroughs will ever be the same.  I could go on and worship this game for another 20 minutes, but I think, if you're not convinced by now, you won't ever be. However, if you're into oldschool RPGS, buy this game and experience one of the most superior titles in video gaming history. Period.

Well, my relationship with the fallout series isn't that lengthy, as I have still yet to complete Fallout and Fallout Tactics along with all the other classic Fallout games.   But as a person who mainly just favors FPS and direct combat and whatnot, when I first got this game, I was plagued with graphics issues.  Things showing up as mixmatch of black,red,blue pixels, overall sound being rather screwed up, and I really started to doubt whether my purchase was worth it.  But recently, while waiting at an airport, I decided to just out of boredom give this game a try.  I dunno what really happened, but the graphics problem was gone. I assume it was patched over the time that I left it to sit in the library, but it was gone.   I watched the intro, I started to play, and there I was, clicking away for hours.  This sort of game with the old-school PC point and click action normally wouldn't be my cup of soup, but for whatever reason this game got me addicted. I paid more attention to story than I ever did with Fallout 3 and New Vegas, and even just laughed at how many cultural references were being made in this game, along with certain 4th wall breaking elements.  Basic story line goes like this. You are a tribal who leaves your settlement to find a GECK, which is supposed to turn barren land into fertile soil, and recreate towns. You go on a looooooong journey, choosing careers, finding companions, but once you come back to your village, you find out that it's been removed, and the lone survivor tells you to go and find them. The rest is up to you to find out. No more spoilers for you, come back next year!  Did I mention careers? Hell, there are also so many reputations/jobs/statuses you can get. Do you want to be a gun-slinging ganster? Do you want to be a dirt-flinging grave digger? Do you want to be a crap-shoveling brahmin excrement remover? Do you want to be a ♥♥♥♥-swinging pornstar? Do you want to get MARRIED? Then this game's got you covered (In more than one way... Grab yer jimmy hats!)  It's almost like GTA in some aspects. You can also get a car! (Conditions do apply though; you need money. And parts. And fuel to get the car operating.) But no biggie, once you get that dream car of yours working (And if you've got enough fuel) you should be zooming around the wasteland (Unless an Enclave patrol pulls you over and shoot you with their futuristic-crap weapons. Then you're sunk unless you've got good stats and good armor. Or mutant soldiers, for that matter.) Want to get drunk? There are multiple types of alcoholic drinks that you can (over)indulge in! Feeling really horny? There are sex-workers GALORE. (Though you will be missing the hot pixel-to-pixel action between your hero and the person you're screwing/being screwed by. Too bad. All you get is a black fade-in screen.) Want to be the 'cool kid' and take drugs? You won't be doing cocaine or heroine, but try some psycho and jet. Oh, some drugs make you stronger and more intelligent, too (Withdrawl's still a ♥♥♥♥♥.)  There are of course, like all other Fallout games, the infamous SPECIAL and karma system. Do you want to be a hero and save the wasteland from evil? Or do you want to join the evils of the wasteland and become infamous? Take your pick, because once you get outta your small podunk settlement, guaranteed, your karma won't be staying at 0. Oh, as for your SPECIAL system, you get a few options: Play with whatever characters the game provides you with (And with their original stats) or just choose that character and modify their stats a wee bit. (Side note, having low intelligence is pretty funny, but on the long run, it will make everything just harder. Take your pick: Funny dialogue, or practical gameplay. Funny dialogue, or practical gameplay.)   One thing did kinda get me a bit iffy about the game, though. It's the infamous talking heads. They're hideous. They're... Rather too smooth-looking, some of them. Almost as if they're made from clay. But other than that, that's pretty much it. Other than those hellspawn wanamingoes. Those you try to avoid.  Yes, there were glitches (obviously not going to be really patched anytime soon), yes, there were frustrating moments in which I forgot to save and was pushed back 4 quests back (losing massive progress and possibly my laptop due to the amount of frustration), but hell, if you know when to save, know what you're clicking (ESPECIALLY the dialogues, mind you, a wrong click can seriously cause big problems. And you can't back away from it unless you exit and load your closest save), know how to read (And if your character has the intelligence to actually say fluent sentences, but it's rather hilarious and frustrating if your character's intelligence is below 3), you wouldn't regret buying this game. Chock-full of quests, interesting characters, jokes, and random encounters with enemies, friends or foe (the special ones are more or less what we'd call now, 'easter eggs')   Oh yeah, unlike the original Fallout (Which gives you 150 days on time limit with the waterchip), there really isn't a time limit for this one. I myself took at least over a year screwing around and actually finding the GECK. Though you should still be aware that the game engine itself can only let you play for 13ish in-game years.   Do I recommend this game?     ♥♥♥♥ yes.    Is it worth $9.99?    Ehhh.... I'd say wait for a sale to happen. I've got my collection at a 75% off sale, and I don't regret that decision one bit.
